channel.title: Simple formula help and question
channel.description:
I have really bad trouble With math logics and thinking about formulas.
I would like to have a formula print all the *region bounds* for a 10000x10000 world
I would like each region to be 11x11 from a center tile (5 each direction)
take this for example:
world starts at 0,0 I would like (-5,5), (5,5), (-5,-5), and (5,5) be the bounds for the tile 0,0 (10,0) would have the bounds of (5,5),(5,-5),(15,-5), and (15, 5) ect
where the *borders* are shared by each adjacent region the bounds are in the format of (-x,+y)(-x,-y)(+x,-y)(+x,+y)
I just want it to print the values so I can modify the format if needed
also: question.. what would be the most efficient way to check which region the user was in? thousands of if statements? or would this be resource heavy.?

item.title: Simple formula help and question
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

He does have a point.

Read full topic

item.title: Simple formula help and question
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:4, topic:548036”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=666942.msg4459602#msg4459602 date=1416872293]
Get a pen and some paper and visualize the problem. Draw the grid and the coordinates and try to see/find a pattern. Then you try to make a mathematical formula that fits the pattern. If you can’t solve a simple problem like this, you will never get anywhere.
[/quote]thats not very polite to say. I have a really hard time with math. and I’m doing fairly good with my life. not everything in the world involves mathematics.[/quote]
Sorry, that was not what I meant :). If you want to get anywhere when it comes to programming you need to work on ways to easier solve problems like this. In my experience visualization is a good way to accomplish this. Another way is to start with a simple version of the problem (1D map with 1D regions) and then modify the algorithm to a more complex problem (2D map). You don’t need advanced math to solve problems like this, just experience of finding the solution. The maths itself is simple enough to be solved by an 8th grader, you just need practice applying what you know.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:5, topic:548036”]you’re funny because everything in the world literally involves math[/quote]i don’t use math at my job. and there are hundreds if not thousands of jobs in the world that don’t involve intermediate+ math.

Read full topic
